Graphical abstract The hydrogenolysis of glycerol is considered a sustainable process to produce 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO). However, the development of a cost-effective solid catalyst and a cleaner process minus the addition of external hydrogen remains a challenge. In the present work, a series of Cu/oxide (SiO2, MgO, Al2O3, and ZnO) catalysts were prepared and evaluated for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The relationships of structure-catalytic properties were probed by thermogravimetric analysis (TG), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption-desorption, temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS). The catalytic activity of Cu/oxide catalysts was in the order of Cu/Al2O3 <Cu/SiO2 ≈Cu/ZnO<Cu/MgO. The Cu/MgO catalysts were identified as highly active catalysts for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol under autogenic pressure without the addition of external hydrogen. When 1.0g Cu/MgO (Cu/MgO=0.5, molar ratio) catalyst and 50g 20wt% aqueous glycerol solution as the feedstock was loaded in a batch autoclave reactor, the conversion of glycerol reached 55% with a selectivity of 68% to 1,2-propanediol at 473K after 6h. Cu0 was identified as the active species both for the catalytic in situ aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol and for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The support basicity played a role in stabilizing the Cu nanoparticles on the support surface. During the catalytic reaction, part of Cu species leached from the MgO support into solvent and meanwhile part of Cu species on the support surface aggregated. The basicity and acidity of the solvent affected the behavior of the Cu/MgO catalysts. This work shows that hydrothermal hydrogenolysis process of glycerol is a facile process and the cost-effective Cu/MgO is worth further development for future industrial practice. Keywords Hydrogenolysis Glycerol Copper Magnesium oxide 1,2-Propanediol Hydrothermal treatment 1 Introduction Glycerol(1,2,3-propanetriol) is produced as an unavoidable by-product in the saponification process in the soap industry [1,2] and in the transesterification process in the biodiesel (fatty acid methyl esters, FAME) industry [3–5]. Both processes are based primarily on bio-based triglycerides as a main feedstock. In addition, it is also possible to produce glycerol from microbial fermentation or the enzyme catalysis of starch, from catalytic hydrogenolysis of sorbitol and from catalytic decomposition of lignocellulose [2]. These bioresources all originate in nature from water and carbon dioxide through photosynthesis. Due to such bioavailability of these feedstocks, glycerol, with non-toxicity, good reactivity and applicability, is now considered as one of renewable platform chemicals and has therefore captured attention from both academia and industry [6,7]. The last decade has witnessed an upsurge in scientific research on the catalytic conversion of glycerol. A broad spectrum of valuable derivatives, such as fuels, fuel additives, fine chemicals, and polymers, can be practically or potentially produced from glycerol through properly-chosen catalytic reactions. The reactions include catalytic reforming of glycerol, catalytic hydrogenolysis of glycerol, catalytic oxidation of glycerol, catalytic dehydration of glycerol, catalytic esterification of glycerol, catalytic etherification of glycerol, catalytic acetalization of glycerol, catalytic carboxylation of glycerol, and catalytic chlorination of glycerol [1,2,6,7]. Among them, one of the most attractive processes is the selectively catalytic hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) [8,9]. One major reason is that 1,2-PDO can be used as a building block to produce polyesters of high performance. However, the present process to produce 1,2-PDO is still based on multi-step reactions using petroleum-derived propylene as the feedstock. It typically involves the selective oxidation of propylene to propylene oxide and subsequent hydrolysis of propylene oxide to 1,2-PDO [10]. Such a process is time-consuming, energy-intensive and costly. Moreover, in the long term, the petroleum-based process cannot be sustained with the dwindling fossil crude oil resources. In contrast, the catalytic hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO provides an alternative route to the production of 1,2-PDO in a simpler and more sustainable way [13,25]. Such a new process is expected to become increasingly competitive and lucrative on the condition that an effective heterogeneous catalytic process is developed. In this context, seeking a catalyst of high performance is a major priority. Currently, catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol with hydrogen include supported Pt, Ru, Rh or Ir catalysts [11,12] and supported Cu and Ni catalysts [13–17]. The bimetallic catalysts, such as Cu with noble metals, have also been reported [18,19]. Undoubtedly, Cu and Ni-based catalysts are significantly more economical than the noble metal-based catalysts [20–23]. Nevertheless, in most cases, the catalytic hydrogenolysis reactions in the presence of these catalysts are usually carried out at high temperatures with the addition of external hydrogen under high pressure. Many studies suggested that high pressure appeared to be essential for a good conversion and a high selectivity to 1,2-PDO, due primarily to the low solubility of hydrogen in aqueous glycerol solution [2,6]. Initial H2 pressure of 0.5–10.0MPa and heating temperatures of 393–513K are usually employed [2,24,25]. To ensure operational safety and reduce energy consumption, the use of low pressure for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol is desired [26]. Likewise, to facilitate an environmental-friendly and sustainable process, the use of external hydrogen is not recommended as industrial hydrogen is currently derived from non-renewable natural gas, coal or petroleum [27]. Recently, several studies [28–32] proved that in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol the hydrogen could be formed and used in situ for when a multifunctional catalyst was judiciously designed and employed. Such a creative methodology opens a cost-effective, energy-saving, and simpler route to produce 1,2-PDO from the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. In a pioneering work, D’ Hondt et al. reported that a bifunctional Pt /NaY zeolite catalyst was able to catalyze the hydrogenolysis of glycerol without any addition of external hydrogen and convincingly proposed that the hydrogen was generated in situ by aqueous phase reforming (APR) of glycerol [30]. Following this work, several other bimetallic catalysts including Pd/Fe2O3 [28,31,32], Raney® Ni [32], Pt/Al2O3 [29] and Pt-Sn [33] have also been reported to catalyze the hydrogenolysis of glycerol without any use of external hydrogen. Others have reported that without the external addition of hydrogen, the use of a mixed catalyst consisting of 5wt% Ru /Al2O3 and 5wt% Pt /Al2O3 for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol at 493K resulted in a 50% conversion of glycerol with a 47% selectivity to 1,2-PDO [29]. More recently, Soares et al. [34] revealed that PtFe/Al2O3 catalyzed both the APR of glycerol and the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The hydrogen for the glycerol hydrogenolysis came from in situ glycerol reforming and thus the catalysts resulted in better selectivity towards 1,2-PDO than Pt/Al2O3. Because hydrogen is inherently generated from the in situ catalytic APR of glycerol, it is also possible to add methanol [35], ethanol [28], and formic acid [36] into the reactor for the APR to yield hydrogen. However, in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol minus the addition of external hydrogen one issue remains: namely thus far catalysts have been mostly based on a noble metal as the active component and acidic oxides as the support [37,38]. In this context, it is worth noting that cheaper Cu-based catalysts are also active in APR and it is therefore possible to use it for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol without external hydrogen [39]. However, the effects of the acidic and alkaline supports, reaction conditions, the deactivation, and the solvent on the in situ hydrogenolysis of glycerol remain elusive [40,41]. Here we explored a simple hydrothermal catalytic hydrogenolysis of glycerol without the addition of external hydrogen into the reactor. By comparing Cu/SiO2, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZnO, and Cu/MgO catalysts, the effects of the acidity and basicity of the supports on the catalytic performance and the interactions therein were investigated. Meanwhile, the active species on the Cu/MgO, the effects of reaction conditions, the deactivation, and the choice of solvent were explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Catalysts The typical procedures for the preparation of Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZnO, and Cu/MgO catalysts primarily by coprecipitation and reduction reactions are described as follows: Cu/Al2O3 catalyst – 6.07g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99.5%) and 9.47g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O (99.0%) at a molar ratio of Cu/Al=1.0 were dissolved in 500mL of distilled water. Next, 500mL of an aqueous K2CO3 solution (0.2M) was dripped at a constant rate into the Cu(NO3)2/Al(NO3)3 solution under magnetic stirring at room temperature. This led to a slurry of co-precipitated Cu/Al hydroxide. The slurry was kept stirring for 30min and then aged for 4h. Subsequently, the solid was separated by centrifugation and washed three times using 250mL distilled water each time. After being dried overnight at 383K, the solid was crushed and ground into powder. The powder was then calcined at 673K for 3h. Prior to the use as catalyst, the powder was reduced under a H2 flow in a tubular oven at 573 K for 3h. Following the similar procedure, Cu/MgO, Cu/ZnO catalysts were prepared using Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (99%) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (99%) as the staring materials for MgO and ZnO, respectively. The Cu/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by a precipitation-gel method following a process reported in the literature [42]. First, at room temperature, 500mL of aqueous K2CO3 (0.2M) solution was dripped into aqueous Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.05M) solution under magnetic stirring. Then, 1.50g fumed nano-silica (99.8%, 380m2/g) was added, forming a mixed gel. The gel was stirred continuously for 30min and aged for 4h. Thereafter, the gel slurry was centrifuged, washed, dried, calcined in air and reduced in a hydrogen flow under the same conditions as described above. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were recorded on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO powder diffractometer in the 2θ range of 5–80° using Cu Kα1 radiation (λ=1.54056Å) operated at 40kV 30mA. The crystallite size D of each catalyst was estimated according to the Scherrer equation [43] as follows D = K λ β c o s θ where λ, B, and θ are the X-ray wavelength, the full width at half maximum of the diffraction peak (FWHM) and the Bragg diffraction angle, respectively. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments for measuring pore size distribution and BET surface area of the catalyst samples were conducted on an ASAP 2020 instrument analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed at 523K for 10h. The surface area was calculated using the Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller (BET) method, while pore size distributions were calculated using the Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) method applied to the desorption leg of the isotherms. Thermogravimetrical (TG) and derivative thermogravimetrical (DTG) analyses of fresh and used catalysts were carried out using a thermo-gravimetric analyser (Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC). In each measurement, the sample was heated in a 38mL/min air flow from 323 to 1173K at a heating rate of 10K/min. Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) was conducted on a Micromeritics 2920 instrument. The as-synthesized samples (without H2 reduction) (100mg) were purged in a He flow (30ml/min) at 573K for 1h. Next, the sample was exposed to 5% H2/He mixture gas (30ml/min) at 80°C for 1h and then purged with He for 1h to remove excess H2. TPR analysis was carried out from 353 to 1173K at a heating rate of 10K/min. The desorption curves were monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), and the area under the peak was integrated using the software Origin 8 to determine the amount of desorbed H2. The temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was conducted on a Micromeritics 2920 instrument. In a typical experiment, the as-synthesized sample, which had undergone H2 reduction, was packed in one arm of a U-shaped quartz cell on a quartz wool bed. Prior to TPD studies, the catalyst sample (100mg) was purged in a He gas flow (30ml/min) at 573K for 1h. Thereafter, the sample was saturated by introducing 10% CO2/He mixture gas (30ml/min) to pass the sample at 353K for 1h and then purged with He for 1h to remove physisorbed CO2. TPD analysis was carried out from 353 to 1173K at a heating rate of 10K/min for CO2 desorption. The desorption curves were monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), and the area under the peak was integrated using the software Origin 8 to determine the amount of desorbed CO2. X-ray photoelectron spectra were recorded using a Kratos AXIS ULTRA DLD spectrometer incorporating a 165mm hemispherical electron energy analyser. The incident radiation was Monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6eV) at 45W (15kV, 3mA). Survey (wide) scans were taken at an analyzer pass energy of 160eV and multiplex (narrow) higher resolution scans at pass energy of 20–40eV. Survey scans were carried out with 1.0eV steps and a dwell time of 100ms. Narrow higher resolution scans were run with 0.05ev steps and 200ms dwell time. Base pressure in the analysis chamber was 7.6×10−9 torr. The area of each peak was calculated using XPS peaks software after subtracting a Shirley or Tougaard background and fitting the experimental peak to Gauss-Lorentz curves in order to more accurately determine the binding energy of the different element core levels. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was performed with a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer (Nicolet Instrument Company, USA) at room temperature using KBr pellets. The spectra were collected over the range 4000–400cm−1 by 32 scans with a spectral resolution of 4cm−1. The size and morphology of the fresh and used catalysts were determined by a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Philips-FEI, Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin). Powders of the catalysts samples were dispersed in ethanol with ultrasound, and drops were deposited on Cu grids coated with amorphous carbon films. In order to detect the leaching of copper element, the composition of the spent 0.5 Cu/MgO catalyst was determined via inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on a Perkin Elmer Nexion 300 instrument after the sample was dissolved in nitric acid in microwave treatment. 2.3 Catalytic activity All the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis reactions were carried out in a Teflon(PTFE)-lined stainless steel autoclave (100mL). For each reaction 50g glycerol solution and a calculated amount of catalyst (Table 1 ) were introduced to the autoclave. The reaction start time was established when the oven reached set temperature and was shut off. After finishing the activity test, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature and liquid products were analyzed using gas chromatography (Shimadzu 2014 GC) with a capillary column (ATFFAP, 30m×0.32mm×0.33μm) connected to flame ionization detector (FID). The conditions for the analysis were: injector, 493K; oven, 423K for 5min, heating rate 10K/min, from 423K to 473K; detector, 513K; injection volume of 0.2μL; split ratio, 1/50; column flow, 1mL/min. The products were also identified by a GC–MS instrument (6890N, Agilent, USA). In the experiments, 1,2-PDO, ethanol and acetol were detected in the liquid products. Gaseous products were not analyzed. The conversion of glycerol and selectivity of products were then calculated. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Effect of the type of support on catalytic performances The four oxide supports used can be categorized into two classes: MgO and ZnO oxides are basic; Al2O3 is acidic and SiO2 is nearly neutral [44]. In the presence of MgO, Al2O3, ZnO or SiO2 supported Cu catalysts, hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol could proceed without the addition of any external gas into the reactor (Table 1). Nevertheless, the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to 1,2-PDO depended heavily on the nature of the support. Though the loading amount of Cu species was equal, the Cu catalysts supported on MgO, Al2O3, ZnO or SiO2 exhibited considerably different conversion of glycerol and a selectivity to 1,2-PDO (Table 1). The activity of supported Cu catalysts appeared in an order of Al2O3 <SiO2 ≈ZnO<MgO (Table 1). The Cu/Al2O3 catalyst and the Cu/SiO2 catalyst gave lower selectivity to 1,2-PDO than the Cu/ZnO catalyst and the Cu/MgO catalyst. The data implied that for the supported Cu catalysts, the basic support was more favorable to the formation of 1,2-PDO than the acidic support. Theoretically, the acidic sites on acidic support will not only readily catalyze in the dehydration reaction [45] but also promote the CC bond cleavages via an acidic cracking mechanism [39], thereby leading to a high conversion of glycerol, as indicated by the behavior of Cu/Al2O3 (Table 1). Over the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, around 45% conversion of glycerol was achieved. However, the acidity appeared not to be conducive for the formation of 1,2-PDO. Thus there was a much lower selectivity on Cu/Al2O3 than those on Cu/MgO and Cu/ZnO. As revealed by CO2-TPD detection (Fig. 1 ), following loading of Cu on the oxide support, the basicity exhibited distinct distributions. Due to the integration of Cu and the oxides, the sites for CO2 adsorption can be categorized as follows: the strongly physical CO2-adsorption sites (CO2-desorbed at around 347K) on all the four catalysts; weakly chemical CO2-adsorption sites (CO2-desorbed at around 540–556K) typically on Cu/Si and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts; strongly chemical CO2-adsorption sites (CO2-desorbed >623K) typically on Cu/Al2O3 Cu/MgO and ZnO catalysts. Moreover, the basicity strength on the Cu/MgO and ZnO catalysts proved to be strongest. It was noted that activity is influenced by the support basicity of Cu/Oxide catalysts. Cu/MgO and Cu/ZnO appeared favorable to the formation of 1,2-PDO. But the two catalysts appeared much different in the catalytic activity in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The conversion of glycerol over the Cu/MgO catalyst reached 47.8%, whereas the one over the Cu/ZnO catalyst was 7.0%. First, the large gap around 40% in the catalytic activity can be reasonably ascribed to the difference in the surface basicity of the MgO and ZnO, Comparatively, the Cu/MgO catalysts showed the remarkable potential in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. 3.2 Interactions between support and Cu species As illustrated by the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of Cu/MgO, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZnO and Cu/SiO2 catalysts in hydrogen flow (Fig. 2 ), metal-support interactions were present, which led to the difference in the reduction of CuOx to Cu. Cu oxide on ZnO and MgO can be more easily reduced than that on SiO2 and Al2O3. For the former, the reduction occurred around 498–506K, by contrast, the reduction of the latter occurred at higher temperatures at 429–560K. Moreover, due to the Cu-support interactions, the reduction reactions occurred on SiO2 and Al2O3 in two steps. The metal-support interactions can be detected by a reverse reaction, namely oxidation, as determined by thermogravimetrical (TG) and derivative thermogravimetrical measurements (DTG) in air flow conducted for both the fresh and spent Cu/MgO, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZnO and Cu/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 3 ). As observed from Fig. 3B, Cu0 species existed on all the fresh Cu/MgO, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZnO and Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The mass loss of the first stage at temperatures around 363K was attributed to the removal of weakly adsorbed water on the surface of the catalysts [46]. The two-stage mass increase at higher temperatures was caused by the stepwise oxidation of Cu0 with oxygen in the air flow. The peak at the lower temperatures was attributed to the oxidation of Cu0 to Cu+ and the peak at the higher temperatures to the oxidation of Cu+ to Cu2+ [47]. Many previous studies suggested that the peaks occurred at higher temperatures indicating that Cu particles existed in a more stable form on the surface of the catalyst due to the interactions between the Cu species and the support [47]. In regards to the fresh Cu/Al2O3 sample, the DTG profile had two peaks at 450 and 623K, whereas regarding the fresh Cu on basic supports (MgO and ZnO), the corresponding two peaks shifted towards higher temperatures (Fig. 3B). Clearly, there were stronger interactions between basic supports and Cu species. Such interactions may have stabilized the Cu nanoparticle, as observed by the measurement of crystallite size of Cu from XRD (Table 1). In this aspect, acidic supports proved unfavorable. As such, the uses of basic supports MgO and ZnO can remarkably result in the formation of stabilized Cu0 particle, as reflected by their oxidation at higher temperatures. 3.3 Crystalline phases of Cu species and support As further determined by XRD (Fig. 4 ) for the fresh and spent Cu/MgO, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZnO and Cu/SiO2 catalysts, the reflections of metallic Cu at 43.5°, 50.7° and 74.2° (2 theta), which can be caused by the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes from metallic Cu (JCPDS file no. 85-1326), were all detected. The XRD diffraction peaks of Cu became narrower and much higher in the used catalysts in comparison to the fresh catalysts (Fig. 4). Regarding the used samples, the increased reflection intensity from metallic Cu could be attributed to a certain increase in the crystallinity of Cu nanoparticles, due possibly to the migration, aggregation and growth of active Cu nanoparticles on the support surface under hydrothermal conditions (Table 1) [48]. According to the Scherrer equation [43], the crystallite sizes of fresh and used Cu/Al2O3 catalysts, for example, were 11 and 104nm, respectively. Before and after reaction, the change of Cu nanoparticles on the acidic support was considerably more than that on basic support. The phenomenon further proved that acidic Al2O3 and basic MgO as supports had varying impacts on Cu species with distinct interactions between the support and Cu, thereby leading to different catalytic performances. It is also noteworthy that the characteristic reflections of CuO were observed in the fresh Cu/MgO (2θ=35.5°, 38.7° and 48.8°), Cu/ZnO (2θ=35.6°, 38.8° and 48.9°) and Cu/Al2O3 (2θ=35.4° and 38.7°) catalysts (Fig. 4) (JCPDS file no. 80-0076) [49]. Referring to the results of the H2-TPR (Fig. 2), this may be because Cu oxide catalysts were not completely reduced to metallic Cu. Furthermore, it was noted that for such high active Cu nanoparticles on those support, any trace amount oxygen during operation can lead to oxidation to form trace CuO. The high activity of such Cu nanoparticles was also observed during experiments. The fresh catalysts could readily ignite a piece of paper when poured onto it despite the catalyst being completely cooled down to room temperature after H2-reduction. Moreover, the probability of the occurrence was influenced by the metal-support interactions. Interestingly, after the Cu/MgO was used for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol, the characteristic reflections of CuO become negligible. For one possible reason, during the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol in the closed reactor, the catalytic APR of glycerol in situ generated high active hydrogen, thus allowing the reduction of trace Cu oxide species to occur under hydrothermal reaction conditions [50,51,52]. Another explanation is the leaching of CuO2 species, as by detected by ICP-OES analysis of the used catalysts. For example, comparing the fresh and used 0.5Cu/MgO sample, the amount of Cu was found to be 12.8 and 8.8mmol Cu/g catalyst, respectively. In addition, the characteristic reflections of Cu2O (JCPDS file no. 01-1142) were observed in fresh Cu/SiO2 and Cu/Al2O3, but not in fresh Cu/MgO and Cu/ZnO. Moreover, the Cu2O phase in the used Cu/SiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalyst samples remained, indicating that the Cu2O phase was more stable in the reaction system under hydrothermal autogenic pressure after 23h. These observations further revealed that acidic support and basic supports had a significant effect on the reduction, stabilization and catalysis of Cu species on the surface of the support. Taken together, the data suggested that for Cu/MgO and Cu/ZnO, Cu0 was the active metal for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO. 3.4 Effect of the molar ratio of Cu/MgO Regarding the activity of a series of Cu/MgO catalysts with different Cu/MgO molar ratios in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol (Fig. 5 ), when the molar ratio of Cu/MgO was increased from 0.1 to 1.0, the conversion of glycerol decreased substantially from around 73% to 48%, whereas the selectivity to 1,2-PDO increased from 44% to 68%, then decreased to 27%. Over the 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, the highest selectivity to 1,2-PDO (68%) was obtained. For the highest Cu loading on the support, namely for the catalysts 1.0Cu/MgO, the lowest activity among all tested catalysts was observed. Generally, with an increase of the number of copper sites, as caused by an increase in the molar ratio of Cu to MgO, the catalytic activity in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol increased. However, this rule can only be applied in a limited range of Cu loadings. At higher Cu loadings, Cu particles easily aggregated [53] and not all Cu atoms were thought to be availably active, as reflected here by the catalytic behavior of the 1.0Cu/MgO sample. Moreover, the phase and the crystallite sizes of Cu species and even the MgO particles on the Cu/MgO catalysts with different Cu/Mg ratios proved to be different (Fig. 5). The reflections from the Cu phase and MgO phase were all observed for 0.1Cu/MgO, 0.2Cu/MgO, 0.5Cu/MgO and 1.0Cu/MgO catalysts. Reflections of CuO were not observed on the 0.1Cu/MgO catalyst, but were observed for the 0.5Cu/MgO catalysts. Moreover, the intensity of the reflections from MgO declined with increasing Cu loading in the catalysts. The crystallite sizes of Cu and MgO particles of a series of catalysts were calculated according to the Scherrer equation [43] (Table 2 ). For the 0.2Cu/MgO sample, the calculated crystallite sizes of MgO were 7.85nm and for 0.5Cu/MgO, it was 7.05nm. For the two catalysts, the calculated crystallite sizes of Cu were nearly the same (28.94nm). Over all catalysts, the difference in the conversion of glycerol was less than the difference in the selectivity to 1,2-PDO. This meant that under such a circumstance, the crystallite sizes of Cu and MgO particles affected both the APR reaction and the subsequent hydrogenolysis reaction, hence leading to a different selectivity to 1,2-PDO. 3.5 Surface and basicity of Cu/MgO catalysts The amount of Cu loading onto MgO also affected texture. When the Cu loading increased from 0.1:1 to 1:1 (molar ratio, Cu: MgO), SBET decreased sharply from 156.8 to 29.0m2/g; there was also a slight reduction in the total pore volume. Conventionally, high loadings of Cu on the MgO support can lead to the formation of CuxO and Cu clusters, which will block the pores of MgO [53]. As a result, the specific surface area significantly decreased. Accordingly, decreased surface area and the aggregation of Cu nanoparticles led to the decrease in conversion of glycerol. The type of basic sites of the 0.5Cu/MgO and 1.0Cu/MgO sample were determined by CO2-TPD (Fig. 6 ). For both samples, there were three stages of CO2-desorption, but the amount and desorption temperature, which is usually ascribed to the number and the strength of relevant basic sites, appeared different. Generally, desorption at around 374–385K was attributed to physical adsorption on the surface of the MgO. The desorption at around 502- 655K was attributed to the weak and strong chemical adsorption of CO2 onto MgO (—OH and CO2 pair). By contrast, the 0.5Cu/MgO sample possessed more and stronger basic sites than the 1.0 Cu/MgO [54]. This was a reasonable outcome as the 0.5Cu/MgO sample contained more MgO than the 1.0Cu/MgO sample. It suggested that both the number and the strength of basic sites should be finely chosen considering the catalytic performances. This could partly explain the fact that comparatively speaking, the 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst appeared better. In addition, the H2-TPR process detected the Cu—MgO interactions (Fig. 6). Higher contents of MgO the in the catalyst meant that the CuO was more easily reduced by H2. This was in agreement with the results for different supports as discussed in preceding subsections. Thus, here the 0.5Cu/MgO was screened as the one with relatively appropriate basic sites and Cu loading, which resulted in the best catalytic performance in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO without external hydrogen. 3.6 Effect of reaction conditions As such, in the presence of the 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, the effects of such reaction conditions as reaction time, temperature, glycerol concentration, and the amount of the catalyst loaded in the hydrothermal reactor was further investigated. The conversion of glycerol gradually increased with the increase of the amount of the catalyst, whereas the selectivity to 1,2-PDO increased sharply (Fig. 7 A). As the amount of the catalyst put in the reactor increased from 0.16g to 1.23g, the selectivity to 1,2-PDO remarkably increased from 16 to 70%. It was deduced that with the increase in amount of catalysts, there was a greater number of available active sites for in situ producing hydrogen, thereby promoting the overall hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. In the presence of 0.4g of the 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, a considerable change in the conversion of glycerol was observed up to a reaction time of 6h (Fig. 7B). Approximately 44% conversion of glycerol and 26% selectivity to 1,2-PDO was achieved when the reaction proceeded for 6h. But further increasing reaction time to 23h, the change in conversion of glycerol and selectivity to 1,2-PDO was marginal. As the temperature increased from 433–493K, the selectivity to 1,2-PDO increased almost five times and reached its maximal value (23%) at 473K, then decreased to 20% (Fig. 7C). Although the conversion of glycerol remained at 64% at 433–453K, it then decreased when the temperature further rose to 493K. It can be postulated, therefore, that the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol involved three reactions: the reforming of glycerol leading to the complete decomposition of glycerol (Eq. (1)), the WGS reaction (Eq. (2)) and the hydrogenolysis of glycerol (Eq. (3)). Hydrogenolysis of glycerol can take advantage of hydrogen generated from the aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol (Eq. (1)) and the WGS reaction (Eq. (2)). The aqueous reforming of glycerol is an endothermic reaction [55]. The WGS reaction is an exothermic reaction [56]. Catalytic hydrogenolysis of glycerol is an exothermic reaction [57]. Namely, higher temperatures favored the aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol, whereas lower temperatures favored the WGS reaction and the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [58]. Therefore, the overall conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to 1,2-PDO were comprehensively caused by such multiple reactions, which varied remarkably upon time and temperature. This is also confirmed by the fact that when the amount of glycerol in the reactor increased, namely when aqueous glycerol solution was increased from 10 to 60wt%, the conversion of glycerol drastically fell from 58% to 25% and the selectivity to 1,2-PDO from 20% to 12% (Fig. 7D). As seen from multiple reactions (Eqs. (1) and (2)), water simultaneously acts as a solvent, a medium and a reactant for forming hydrogen. Large excess water could adjust viscosity of pure glycerol and was beneficial for glycerol molecule adsorbed onto the active sites on the surface of the Cu/MgO catalyst. Meanwhile, the presence of excess water enhanced the reforming of glycerol (Eqs. (1)) and the WGS reaction (Eq. (2)). Clearly, there were some changes to the catalyst. The change of particle size between the fresh and used 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst was observed by TEM imaging. For the fresh 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, the average particle size was about 30nm (Fig. 8 A and Table 2). However, for the used 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, the particles grew large to be in the range of 50–75nm (Fig. 8B). Some particles even aggregated to form much larger particles (Fig. 8C). In addition, the change of the Cu species on the support surface was detected by XPS for the fresh and used 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst (Fig. 9 ). The peak at 934.7eV and the satellite band were characteristic of Cu2+ [59], while the peak at 932.5eV corresponded to Cu0 or to Cu+. Nonetheless, the spectra of the Cu LMM Auger peaks indicated the existence of Cu+ species for this fresh sample (916.3eV Auger kinetic energy [60]) (Table 3 ). According to the XRD pattern and the catalytic activity of the fresh 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst (Fig. 5), Cu0 particles were an active species. It was noticed that such active Cu0 nanoparticle catalyst was easily oxidized to Cu+ when it came into contact with air or even trace oxygen. Trace oxygen cannot be avoided when making samples for the XPS experiments and running XRD analyses. Moreover, Cu0 can also be oxidized in the hydrothermal system if any trace of oxygen remains in the aqueous glycerol solution. For the used 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, a satellite peak at 940–946eV in the XPS was indicative of Cu2+. In addition, a broad peak in the range of 930–935eV was observed and resulted from by various Cu species. The wide Cu 2p3/2 signals obtained for the used 0.5Cu/MgO could be fitted into three peaks after deconvulation (Fig. 9). One peak at 933.5eV was assigned to Cu2+ of CuO. Another peak at 934.9eV was also due to Cu2+ of CuCO3 [60]. As discussed in 3.1.3, CO2 generated simultaneously with hydrogen in WGS reaction. Therefore, a little CuCO3 was formed. The third was a part of Cu+ species as evidenced by the 917.3eV Auger kinetic energy [34]. The molar ratio of Cu and Mg of near-surface used 0.5Cu/MgO was 1.4, which is less than that of the fresh 0.5Cu/MgO (3.7). This suggests copper leaching from the catalyst. According to the ICP-OES analysis of the fresh and spent catalyst (0.5Cu/MgO sample), the amount of Cu leaning even reached 31.3%. Finally, preliminary investigations were made into the effects of different solvents on the 0.5Cu/MgO in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol (Fig. 10 ). When using methanol as a solvent, the conversion of glycerol was 72% over the fresh 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, whereas the conversion was 79% over the used 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst. This meant that very little change occurred to the catalysts when methanol was used as solvent. It is worth noting that methanol as the solvent can promote the reaction because the possible occurrence of reforming of methanol in the presence of Cu catalysts was beneficial for producing more hydrogen [61,62]. In addition, it has been reported that treatment of MgO in different solvents affected the catalytic performances remarkably [63,64]. When isopropanol was used as the solvent, the conversion of glycerol was 89% over the fresh 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst, and then decreased to 48% over the reused 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst. By contrast, when ethanol was used as the solvent, a higher conversion of 87% of glycerol and a lower selectivity to 1,2-PDO (28%) was obtained. The major product appeared to be an unknown white solid as observed directly during experiments. The 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst was unrecoverable from the solid. When using formic acid as a solvent, a conversion of glycerol (34%) and selectivity to 1,2-PDO (3%) was lower than using water as a solvent. Strong acidic reaction conditions were not favorable for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol and these phenomena were similar to the use of the acidic support. Moreover, during the experiments, it was found that the stainless steel autoclave can be readily eroded by any acid. Therefore, the 0.5Cu/MgO catalyst used with formic acid as the solvent was unsuitable to be reused. 4 Conclusion Without any use of an external hydrogen and pressure, the hydrogenolysis of glycerol was feasible under hydrothermal autogenic pressure in an autoclave batch reactor with Cu/MgO as the catalyst. When comparing MgO, ZnO, SiO2, and Al2O3 supported Cu catalysts, it was found that the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to 1,2-PDO were influenced by the nature of the support due primarily the interactions between the metal and the support. Basic supports appeared more favorable to the formation of 1,2-PDO than neutral and acidic supports. The interactions between MgO and Cu species can stabilize the Cu nanoparticles and influence the reduction of Cu precursors. Cu0 nanoparticles, instead of Cu+ and Cu2+, were the active species catalyzing the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO. The catalytic activity of Cu/MgO catalysts was also related to the amount and the size of Cu nanoparticles on the surface of the support. The aggregation of active copper nanoparticles took place when the molar ratio of Cu/MgO was increased, thereby leading to the decrease in the conversion of glycerol. When 1.0g Cu/MgO (Cu/MgO=0.5) catalyst and 50g 20wt% aqueous glycerol solution were added into the autoclave reactor, the conversion of glycerol reached 55%, with a selectivity of 68% to 1,2-propanediol at 473K after 6h. Under such reaction conditions, the in situ aqueous reforming of glycerol to hydrogen, and the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis to 1,2-PDO with the hydrogen, was considered to occur synergistically. After the Cu/MgO catalyst was used once, there were the aggregation of Cu nanoparticles on the support and the leaching of Cu into the water. Hydrothermal conditions in the presence of the solvent, for example water or alcohol, affected the Cu/MgO catalyst. The acidic and basic solvents led to different catalytic performances. In summary, the present work demonstrated a facile hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol over Cu/MgO catalyst to produce 1,2-PDO. It was revealed that the interactions between MgO-Cu play a pivotal role in the physical and chemical properties of the Cu/MgO catalyst, which in turn lead to distinct catalytic behavior in the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The findings suggested that the Cu/MgO catalyst is worth further development for the facile hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol in regard to both its theoretical significance and its contribution to environmental-friendly industrial practice. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenolysis of glycerol is considered a sustainable process to produce 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO). However, the development of a cost-effective solid catalyst and a cleaner process minus the addition of external hydrogen remains a challenge. In the present work, a series of Cu/oxide (SiO2, MgO, Al2O3, and ZnO) catalysts were prepared and evaluated for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The relationships of structure-catalytic properties were probed by thermogravimetric analysis (TG), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption-desorption, temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS). The catalytic activity of Cu/oxide catalysts was in the order of Cu/Al2O3 <Cu/SiO2 ≈Cu/ZnO<Cu/MgO. The Cu/MgO catalysts were identified as highly active catalysts for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol under autogenic pressure without the addition of external hydrogen. When 1.0g Cu/MgO (Cu/MgO=0.5, molar ratio) catalyst and 50g 20wt% aqueous glycerol solution as the feedstock was loaded in a batch autoclave reactor, the conversion of glycerol reached 55% with a selectivity of 68% to 1,2-propanediol at 473K after 6h. Cu0 was identified as the active species both for the catalytic in situ aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol and for the hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol. The support basicity played a role in stabilizing the Cu nanoparticles on the support surface. During the catalytic reaction, part of Cu species leached from the MgO support into solvent and meanwhile part of Cu species on the support surface aggregated. The basicity and acidity of the solvent affected the behavior of the Cu/MgO catalysts. This work shows that hydrothermal hydrogenolysis process of glycerol is a facile process and the cost-effective Cu/MgO is worth further development for future industrial practice.
coredata.dc:title: Cleaner hydrothermal hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-propanediol over Cu/oxide catalysts without addition of external hydrogen
